definitions: inflict punishment or harm on someone in return for injury or wrong they caused
examples: The hero vowed to avenge his father's death
She wanted to avenge the injustice done to her family

definitions: turn one's eyes or face away from something unpleasant or disturbing
prevent something bad or dangerous from happening by taking action
examples: She averted her eyes from the terrible accident
He averted his gaze when she entered the room
Quick thinking helped avert a major disaster
The pilot's skill averted what could have been a tragedy

definitions: wake up from sleep or cause someone to stop sleeping
make someone become aware of something for the first time
examples: The loud noise awakened the baby from her nap
I usually awaken at six o'clock every morning
The documentary awakened her interest in marine biology
His words awakened a deep longing within her

definitions: inspire someone with a feeling of wonder mixed with fear or respect
examples: The grand canyon's beauty awed the first-time visitors
Her incredible performance awed the entire audience

definitions: chop or cut something using a sharp tool with a heavy blade
suddenly cancel or get rid of something like plans jobs or services
examples: He axed the fallen tree into smaller pieces
The lumberjack axed through the thick wooden beam
The company axed hundreds of jobs during the recession
The network axed the show after poor ratings

definitions: make the crying sound that a sheep or lamb naturally produces
examples: The lambs baaed loudly when they saw their mother
Sheep baa constantly in the meadow during spring

definitions: have the opposite effect from what was intended causing harm to the planner
make a loud explosive sound from an engine or exhaust system
examples: His plan to impress her completely backfired
The prank backfired when the teacher found out
The old car backfired loudly as it started
The motorcycle backfired when he shifted gears too quickly

definitions: strike something with the back of one's hand or with a reversed motion
examples: She backhanded the tennis ball over the net
He accidentally backhanded the cup off the table

definitions: react with strong negative force against something perceived as harmful or unfair
examples: Voters backlashed against the unpopular new policy
The community backlashed when the park closure was announced

definitions: travel or hike while carrying belongings in a bag worn on the back
examples: They backpacked through Europe for three months
We plan to backpack the mountain trail this weekend

definitions: act as a barrier or support behind something to prevent it from going too far
examples: The government agreed to backstop the failing banks
Emergency funds will backstop the charity if donations fall

definitions: swim by lying on one's back and moving arms and legs in specific motions
examples: She backstroked across the pool in record time
Learning to backstroke takes practice and good coordination

definitions: return along the same route that was previously traveled
reverse one's opinion or withdraw from a previous statement or commitment
examples: We had to backtrack five miles to find the lost keys
The hikers backtracked when they realized they were lost
The politician backtracked on his campaign promises
She had to backtrack after realizing her mistake

definitions: mark or provide someone with an official emblem showing rank or membership
examples: Security badged all visitors before allowing entry
New employees are badged on their first day

definitions: repeatedly ask or pester someone to do something in an annoying way
examples: The children badgered their parents for ice cream
Stop badgering me about cleaning my room

definitions: totally confuse or perplex someone so they cannot understand or explain something
examples: The magician's trick completely baffled the audience
Complex math problems often baffle young students

definitions: remove water from a boat using a container or pump
pay money to release someone from jail before their trial
suddenly leave or abandon a difficult situation or commitment
examples: They had to bail water from the leaking boat
We bailed the canoe after the storm passed
His family bailed him out of jail last night
The lawyer arranged to bail her client immediately
He bailed on the project when it got difficult
She bailed from the party without saying goodbye

definitions: put food on a hook or trap to catch fish or animals
deliberately annoy or provoke someone to get an angry reaction
examples: He baited the hook with worms before fishing
Hunters bait their traps with fresh meat
Stop trying to bait me into an argument
The bully baited him until he lost his temper

definitions: compress and bind something like hay or cotton into large tight bundles
examples: Farmers bale hay during the dry season
The machine can bale a thousand pounds per hour

definitions: hesitate or refuse to proceed with something because of doubt fear or reluctance
examples: The horse balked at jumping over the fence
Many investors balked at the risky business proposal

definitions: trick or deceive someone through elaborate lies or confusing talk
examples: The con artist bamboozled elderly people out of their savings
Don't let fancy words bamboozle you into buying

definitions: cover a wound or injury with strips of material to protect it
examples: The nurse bandaged his injured ankle carefully
She bandaged the cut on her finger

definitions: pass words ideas or objects back and forth between people in discussion
examples: They bandied jokes throughout the entire meeting
Rumors were bandied about the office all week

definitions: force someone to leave a place permanently as an official punishment or decree
examples: The king banished the traitor from the kingdom
She banished all negative thoughts from her mind

definitions: cause a person or business to have no money left to pay debts
examples: The lawsuit could bankrupt the small company
Gambling debts bankrupted him within two years

definitions: participate in or provide an elaborate formal meal for many people
examples: The nobles banqueted in the great hall
The company banqueted its top performers annually

definitions: talk in a playful and teasing way exchanging quick witty remarks
examples: The friends bantered throughout the entire road trip
She loved to banter with her coworkers during breaks

definitions: perform a Christian religious ceremony using water to welcome someone into the faith
give a name to someone or something in a formal or informal ceremony
examples: The priest baptized the baby on Sunday morning
They baptized dozens of new converts that day
The sailors baptized their new ship with champagne
We baptized the puppy Spot because of his markings

definitions: make sharp critical comments intended to hurt or provoke someone
examples: She barbed him about his fashion choices
Critics barbed the actor for his poor performance

definitions: cook food especially meat on a grill over an open fire or hot coals
examples: We barbecue hamburgers every Fourth of July
Dad loves to barbecue ribs on weekends

definitions: cook food especially meat on a grill over an open fire or hot coals
examples: They barbeque chicken for the family reunion
Let's barbeque some vegetables for dinner tonight

definitions: cut and style hair especially for men as a professional service
examples: He barbers at the local shop downtown
My grandfather barbered for forty years

definitions: discuss and negotiate to reach an agreement about price or terms
examples: She bargained with the vendor for a lower price
Workers bargained for better wages and benefits

definitions: push or move forward roughly without regard for others in the way
examples: He barged through the crowd to reach the exit
Don't just barge into someone's office without knocking

definitions: make the sharp loud cry that dogs and similar animals produce
shout or speak to someone in a harsh commanding voice
examples: The dog barked at every passing stranger
Wolves bark to communicate with their pack
The sergeant barked orders at the new recruits
Don't bark at me like that

definitions: shout loud critical comments at someone performing or speaking in public
examples: Angry fans barracked the referee after the bad call
The crowd barracked the politician during his speech

definitions: attack or overwhelm someone with a rapid succession of questions criticisms or information
examples: Reporters barraged the celebrity with personal questions
The teacher barraged students with homework assignments
